comment._content: This looks familiar. Did we have it before or is it just a common rural architectural style?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: JI was Tyrone, but JI 54 was registered (in 1911-12) to Thomas W. Thompson Raphoe, Co. Donegal.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Maybe not. I'd have rememberd something this ghastly: maps.google.ie/maps?q=Burtonport,+Donegal&hl=en&l...

comment._content: Does the passenger look 72? Perhaps this gentleman

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I think we have our second undeniable chauffeur as well.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Could be. Does he look like a blacksmith?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The gentleman looking into the car could plausibly be James Frank O'Donnell, postmaster and merchant grocer, who was 46 in the 1911 census.

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: With reference to the naval man could he be on leave from the base at Lough Swilly?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Streetview and slightly different OS 25". Suggests this is after the 1904 survey.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Check out the pics of James and his family here (scroll down). I think the lady in the PO door could be daughter Annie, and the two in the other door look like daughter Margaret and second wife Bridget Delia. If so, after 1906 (when they married).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: NIAH and DIA let us down. Only hotel reference I can find is Sweeneys, 1904. There seem to be no (zero) protected structures in Burtonport, although this pile is clearly over 100 years old.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The railway arrived in town in 1903.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000331706 Here is a nice photo with the hotel in the background, and another catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000317919

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: ??? A Norwegian company has taken an extensive plot of ground at Burtonport, Co Donegal, to erect large buildings for developing the whaling industry ??? (Irish Times, Jan 17, 1908)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Looking out the first floor winwo, that could be the eldest daughter, Kate (missed her earlier!).

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: Any idea about the three street urchins standing on the left hand side of the picture?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48236157@N02] Not a clue *yet*, but their clothes look to be of quite a high quality and they don't seem to be barefoot...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: When this picture was taken photography was still a big deal. And getting to see a photographer at work would have attracted attention! Hense the people casually standing around as if it was an every day occurrence. Nice photo!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Mr. O'Donnell had sons James who was 10 in 1911, Patrick and John (3 and 1), plus Dominick in 1917 and Owen sometime later.

comment.author: 72163146@N08
comment._content: According to Burtonport Heritage Group FB page the maid's names were Maggie Gallagher & Cassie Doherty. www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151648081023690&set...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/72163146@N08] The census of 1911 show those two plus Maggie Sweeney.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/72163146@N08] Thanks! So we have Emerson Tennent Herdman in the car? If any of you have a bit of time on your hands, could you let the Burtonport Heritage Group know about this photo? I can't seem to comment, us being a "Page" and all?
